questions.text: A patient came with infective endocarditis. Examination showed gram-positive cocci in chains. What is the likely etiological agent? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus viridans

 

The key points that indicate Streptococcus viridans as the causative agent are:

 

1. The patient has infective endocarditis, which is commonly caused by Streptococcus viridans.

 

 

2. The microscopic examination showed gram-positive cocci arranged in chains, which is a characteristic morphology of Streptococcus viridans.

 

3. The image provided also confirms the presence of gram-positive cocci (violet color) arranged in long chains.

 

4. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Enterococcus typically appear as diplococci (in pairs) and not in chains, ruling them out.

 

5. Streptococcus pyogenes is more commonly associated with rheumatic fever endocarditis rather than infective endocarditis.

 

Gram Positive cocci

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Streptococcus pyogenes: This beta-hemolytic streptococcus is a common cause of rheumatic fever and pharyngitis but not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae: This alpha-hemolytic streptococcus appears as gram-positive diplococci (in pairs) and is a common cause of pneumonia but not a typical cause of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Enterococcus: These gram-positive cocci also appear in pairs (diplococci) and are not commonly associated with infective endocarditis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Streptococcus viridans, an alpha-hemolytic streptococcus found in the normal oral flora, is a common cause of infective endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying heart valve abnormalities or prosthetic heart valves. Its characteristic microscopic appearance of gram-positive cocci arranged in chains is a key diagnostic feature.

questions.text: An infant came with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize galactose properly due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, resulting in symptoms such as vomiting, jaundice, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and oil droplet cataracts. The condition often presents in the neonatal period shortly after the introduction of milk or milk-based formulas, which contain lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose). The inability to process galactose leads to hypoglycemia due to disruption in normal glucose metabolism.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylketonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels. Symptoms typically include intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty body odor, but not jaundice or hypoglycemia. There is no direct association with the symptoms of vomiting or jaundice seen in the presented case.

 

Option C. Wilson disease: Wilson disease is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation, particularly in the liver and brain. Key symptoms include hepatic dysfunction, neurological symptoms like tremors (wing-beating tremors), and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes. However, it does not typically present with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia in infancy.

 

Option D. Menke disease: Menke disease is a disorder of copper transport, characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and deterioration of the nervous system. It does not typically present with jaundice or hypoglycemia. The defining symptoms such as brittle, kinky hair were not noted in the question, making it less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia should be suspected in infants presenting with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia, especially soon after the introduction of milk. Immediate dietary management with lactose-free formulas is critical to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used for the treatment of constipation-predominant Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS-C)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lubiprostone

 

Lubiprostone is specifically indicated for the treatment of IBS-C (IBS with constipation). It functions as a prosecretory agent that activates intestinal chloride channels, increasing intestinal fluid secretion and promoting bowel movements. This mechanism makes it particularly effective for constipation-predominant IBS, helping to alleviate both the constipation and associated discomfort in affected patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholestyramine: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant primarily used to treat bile acid malabsorption (BAM). While it can affect bowel function, it is not indicated for IBS-C treatment and may actually worsen constipation in some patients. It's mainly used when excess bile acids are contributing to diarrhea.

 

Option C. Alosetron: Alosetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist that has a constipating effect and is used in specific cases of severe diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D) in women who have failed conventional therapy. It would be contraindicated in IBS-C as it would worsen constipation.

 

Option D. Rifaximin: Rifaximin is a non-absorbable antibiotic used in IBS-D (diarrhea-predominant IBS), not IBS-C. It targets bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine which may contribute to IBS-D symptoms. It has no established therapeutic role in treating constipation-predominant IBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of IBS should be targeted to the predominant symptom pattern. Lubiprostone specifically addresses constipation in IBS-C by increasing intestinal fluid secretion, whereas other agents like rifaximin are indicated for diarrhea-predominant IBS (IBS-D).

questions.text: Following a stab injury to the chest, the following imaging finding was noted. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process. The X-ray described in the  reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.

Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity. On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space. The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.

 

Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is contraindicated in iron poisoning? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) BAL (British Anti-Lewisite)

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite), also known as dimercaprol, is contraindicated in cases of iron poisoning.

 

BAL should not be used in this case because it can form toxic complexes with iron, exacerbating the condition rather than alleviating it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EDTA: EDTA is a chelating agent used primarily for lead and other heavy metals, but it is not contraindicated in iron poisoning. However, it is not the preferred chelating agent for iron poisoning either.

 

Option C. DTPA: DTPA (Diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid) is another chelating agent used for certain radioactive heavy metals and is not specifically contraindicated in iron poisoning, although it is not used for iron either.

 

Option D. Desferrioxamine: Desferrioxamine is the chelating agent of choice in iron poisoning. It binds to free iron and forms a complex that is excreted in the urine, making it effective in reducing iron levels in cases of acute iron toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) is contraindicated in Cadmium and Iron poisoning.

 

Desferrioxamine is the appropriate chelating agent to use in cases of iron poisoning.

questions.text: Type of tympanoplasty shown in image Below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type 4

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows Type 4 tympanoplasty (Wullstein classification) where:

 

  • The graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate
  • All ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes suprastructure) are absent
  • Only the footplate remains
  • Also called cavum minor tympanoplasty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1

 

  • Simple myringoplasty with intact ossicular chain
  • Graft placed on handle of malleus
  • All ossicles are present and functional

 

Option B. Type 2

 

  • Graft placed on incus or remnant of malleus
  • Partial ossicular defect
  • Malleus absent but incus present

 

Option C. Type 3

 

  • Also called columella tympanoplasty
  • Graft placed on stapes head
  • Malleus and incus absent but stapes suprastructure present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Type 4 tympanoplasty as the procedure where the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes footplate when all ossicles are absent except the footplate.

 

Tympanoplasty –

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus developed the following rhythm. His blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg and he had a feeble pulse. What is the next step of management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DC cardioversion

 

  • The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).
  • The patient is also hemodynamically unstable, as indicated by the low blood pressure (70/40 mm Hg) and feeble pulse.
  • When a patient presents with SVT and hemodynamic instability, immediate rhythm conversion is essential.
  • The recommended treatment in such cases is direct current (DC) cardioversion.
  • This involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to restore a normal rhythm and stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV adenosine: Adenosine temporarily slows or stops the heart's electrical activity and is often the first-line treatment for terminating stable, narrow complex supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). However, in hemodynamically unstable patients, its short-lived effects make it less suitable.

 

Option B. IV diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the rate in atrial fibrillation or flutter and certain types of SVT. In hemodynamically unstable patients, slowing the heart rate without converting the rhythm can be dangerous.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is an antiarrhythmic drug used to treat certain types of atrial fibrillation or flutter. It's not the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable SVT and carries a risk of proarrhythmia, meaning it can sometimes cause new or worsening rhythm problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and hemodynamic instability, direct current (DC) cardioversion is the recommended and most effective treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1744

choices.text: Abortion leading to death of mother
Preventing the child from being born alive

questions.text: IPC Section 314 deals with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abortion leading to death of mother

 

ABORTION IPC’S = 312-316 IPC’S, 317 & 318

 

312 – 316 → Criminal Abortion

 

312 – Criminal abortion with consent of mother (BNS section 88)

 

313 – Criminal abortion without the consent of mother (BNS section 89)

 

314 – Death of mother during criminal abortion (BNS section 90)

 

315 - Preventing a live birth or causing a live born to die after birth (BNS section 91)

 

316 – Causing death of quick born, by a heinous act which could have led to death of mother (ex: - hit on abdomen of mother) (BNS section 92)

 

317 - Abandoning of a child by parents when child age is <12 years (BNS section 93)

 

318 - Concealing the birth of a newborn by secret disposal of dead body (BNS section 94)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC Section 314 deals specifically with the death of the mother during a criminal abortion.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.text: During a histological examination of the oral cavity, which combination of features is typically seen in the hard palate mucosa? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

 

Hard palate is composed of a dense layer of connective tissue covered by a specialized oral mucosa. It is composed of keratinized epithelium, a submucosal layer for support, and contains minor salivary glands. These structures contribute to the function of the hard palate in speech, mastication (chewing), and the initial digestion of food in the oral cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient’s symptoms are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs when alcohol is consumed while taking certain medications, including metronidazole. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This results in symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: Metronidazole overdose would typically present with neurological symptoms such as seizures, neuropathy, and encephalopathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen here, which are triggered by alcohol consumption.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, metabolic acidosis. The context of alcohol consumption and the specific symptoms make methanol poisoning unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, agitation, anxiety, hallucinations, and seizures. It does not present with the acute flushing and gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this case, which are more consistent with a disulfiram-like reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram-like reaction by "CGMP" (mnemonic)

 

C – Cefoperazone

 

G – Griseofulvin

 

M – Metronidazole

 

P – Procarbazine

 

Additionally, sometimes can be caused by Isoniazid and chlorpropamide.

 

This reaction typically includes symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations when alcohol is consumed.

questions.text: Which of the below is the most preferred investigation for parathyroid adenoma localisation? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sestamibi SPECT

 

This is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying parathyroid adenomas. The technique involves the use of a radioactive tracer, typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by hyperactive parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. SPECT provides three-dimensional imaging, improving the localization of hyperactive parathyroid glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT (Computed Tomography): CT scans are not typically the first line of imaging due to the high levels of radiation exposure and the potential need for contrast agents.

 

Option C. Technetium-99m Sestamibi (tech99-Sestamibi) scan: This is a nuclear imaging which uses a gamma camera for imaging.

 

Option D. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is a non-invasive, widely available, and less expensive method to examine the neck for parathyroid adenomas. It is particularly useful in conjunction with Sestamibi scans, as it helps to evaluate the structure of the neck and localize adenomas. However, its effectiveness can be limited by the operator's experience and the patient's anatomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While all these methods can assist in the diagnosis and localization of parathyroid adenomas, Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most effective standalone imaging modality due to its high specificity for active parathyroid tissue and its ability to provide detailed spatial resolution. It is particularly valuable in surgical planning to ensure precise removal of the adenoma.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

Imaging

 

  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

Treatment:

 

Drugs used in osteoporosis are:

 

  1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
  2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
  3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis: Incorrect, as spondylolysis refers to a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebrae, not typically associated with the changes seen in the X-ray provided.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis: Incorrect, this condition involves the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, which would show distinct alignment changes not described in the X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Incorrect, as osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal density and sclerosis of bone, quite the opposite of what is observed in osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis is a condition marked by a decrease in bone density and mass, leading to structural weakening of the bone and increased risk of fractures. Diagnostic imaging such as X-rays can show characteristic changes like "Codfish Vertebra" and is further confirmed by measuring bone mineral density through a DEXA scan. Treatment focuses on inhibiting bone resorption and/or stimulating bone formation through various pharmacological agents.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Optic tract

 

The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

 

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is a type of light reflex. The blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction on illumination, while the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction.

 

It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumors of the optic thalamus.

 

Homonymous hemianopia HH is characteristically seen in optic tract pathway

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve: Incorrect. A lesion in the optic nerve typically results in a loss of vision in the eye served by the affected nerve but does not produce hemianopic pupillary responses. Instead, it might lead to a direct pupillary defect (also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or Marcus Gunn pupil).

 

Option C. Optic radiation: Incorrect. Lesions in the optic radiation cause visual field deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia) but do not affect the pupillary light reflex because the optic radiations carry visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex and are not involved in the reflex arc of the pupil light reflex.

 

Option D. Optic chiasma: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing of nasal retinal fibers at this location. This type of lesion affects the visual fields of both eyes but does not specifically result in a hemianopic pupillary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lesion site for Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is the optic tract, which when damaged, leads to a characteristic pupillary response where the pupil does not react to light shown on the side of the retina corresponding to the damaged tract. This finding is indicative of a post-chiasmal visual pathway issue and is useful for localizing neurological damage in clinical assessments.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisoning? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocarbon

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in two types of poisoning: Hydrocarbon and corrosive poisoning. 

 

Hydrocarbons are substances such as gasoline, kerosene, or certain cleaning agents, which are highly volatile and can easily be aspirated into the lungs during the procedure. This can lead to severe chemical pneumonitis and other respiratory complications, making the risks of gastric lavage significantly higher than any potential benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Gastric lavage is not typically contraindicated in phenytoin poisoning. While it is not the first line of treatment, it can be considered if the patient presents soon after ingestion.

 

Option C. Unknown poisoning within 1 hour: For unknown poisoning, especially if within 1 hour of ingestion, gastric lavage might still be considered, although it is generally falling out of favor due to risks and effectiveness. However, it is not specifically contraindicated.

 

Option D. Paracetamol: Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning. The mainstay of treatment for paracetamol poisoning is N-acetylcysteine (NAC) administration, but if the patient presents early, gastric lavage can be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning due to the high risk of aspiration and subsequent chemical pneumonitis. In any case of poisoning, the potential risks and benefits of gastric lavage must be carefully considered.

questions.text:
To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, what level should the rate of couple protection exceed? [NEET PG 2018]

 

(NRR: Net reproduction rate)
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 60% 

 

The Net Reproduction Rate (NRR) is a measure of the average number of daughters a woman would have if she passed through her lifetime conforming to the age-specific fertility and mortality rates of a given year. An NRR of 1 means that each woman is, on average, having one daughter who survives to reproductive age, thereby replacing herself without population growth or decline.

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) must exceed 60%. This aligns with the scenario where every couple has two children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To achieve the demographic target of NRR=1, the rate of couple protection should exceed 60%. This level of contraceptive use helps in maintaining a stable population by ensuring that each woman, on average, has one daughter who survives to reproductive age.

questions.text: If a woman is undergoing MTP after 24 weeks  of gestation due to congenital anomaly in the fetus , whose presence is not required for authorization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawyer

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) regulations require authorization by a medical board when a pregnancy extends beyond 24 weeks, particularly in cases involving serious congenital anomalies. The board typically comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist—professionals whose expertise is crucial in assessing the risks and conditions related to both the pregnancy and the identified anomaly.

 

A lawyer is not part of this medical board and does not play a role in authorizing MTP, as the decision is purely based on medical assessment rather than legal consultation. The presence of a lawyer is not necessary because the authorization process focuses on the medical justification and safety considerations rather than legal arguments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetrician: The obstetrician is involved in the care of the pregnant woman and is often part of the medical decision-making team, especially when dealing with complex or high-risk pregnancies.

 

Option C. Pediatrician: Pediatricians are essential members of the medical board because they provide expertise on the potential outcomes for the fetus, especially in cases involving congenital anomalies that could impact the fetus's viability or quality of life.

 

Option D. Sonologist: The sonologist's role is crucial as they specialize in ultrasound and imaging, providing detailed assessments of the fetus's condition. Their input is vital in confirming congenital anomalies and guiding the medical board’s decision-making process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP after 24 weeks for congenital anomalies, the medical board's authorization is required and comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist. A lawyer’s presence is not required for this authorization process.

questions.text: Serology of IPV vaccine strains is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1, type 2, type 3

 

Explanation:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3. Although India switched from the trivalent Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) to the bivalent OPV (containing only Type 1 and Type 3) as part of the global switch program in April 2016.

 

The IPV introduced in the national immunization schedule still contains all three poliovirus strains. It is a trivalent vaccine, containing Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3 strains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) introduced in the national immunization schedule of India contains all three strains of the poliovirus: Type 1, Type 2, and Type 3, making it a trivalent vaccine.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the upper GI endoscopy image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal varices

 

The image shows dilated column of veins in the veins suggestive of esophageal varices. They are seen in portal hypertension and present with hematemesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barrett’s esophagus: Characterised by salmon coloured tongue like patches at GE junction

 

 

Option C. Gastric erosions: Lesions seen in stomach due to H. Pylori.

 

 

 

Option D. Esophageal candida: Appear as milky/curdy white patches.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated column of veins in esophagus represent varices.

questions.text: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Explanation:

 

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) includes endometritis, salpingitis, oophoritis, and parametritis. Any interventions like dilatation and curettage (D&C) are contraindicated in active PID due to the risk of exacerbating the infection and causing further complications.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy: D&C is not contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy; however, it is not typically performed in its management as it does not provide any benefit for this condition.

 

Option C. Menstrual irregularities: D&C can be performed to obtain an endometrial biopsy in peri-menopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) if there are no other identifiable causes and if endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy is suspected.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: D&C is not usually performed solely for endometriosis unless there is an associated AUB that needs to be evaluated or treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to the risk of spreading the infection

 

Ref: Page 168, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Most specific sign of Portal Hypertension on Ultrasound is: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Recanalized Umbilical Vein)

 

A recanalized umbilical vein (also known as paraumbilical vein) represents a portosystemic collateral pathway that develops specifically in response to portal hypertension. When portal pressure increases significantly, blood seeks alternative routes from the portal system to the systemic circulation. The normally closed umbilical vein can reopen (recanalize) to establish this collateral pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enlarged Portal Vein Diameter > 13mm - While portal vein dilatation can occur in portal hypertension, it is not the most specific sign. Portal vein diameter can be influenced by multiple factors including body habitus, phase of respiration, and positioning. Additionally, the portal vein may not always enlarge despite significant portal hypertension.

 

Option B. Splenomegaly - Splenomegaly is commonly seen in portal hypertension but lacks specificity since it can result from numerous other conditions including hematologic disorders, infections, and inflammatory conditions that are unrelated to portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Ascites - While ascites is a complication of portal hypertension, it is not specific to this condition. Ascites can develop from multiple other causes including heart failure, hypoalbuminemia, nephrotic syndrome, and peritoneal malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recanalized umbilical vein is the most specific sonographic sign of portal hypertension as it represents a direct pathophysiological response to increased portal pressure, unlike other findings that can result from multiple etiologies.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Potassium

 

Explanation

 

Potassium is involved in peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors.

 

Chemoreceptors are made up of two types of cells, type I or glomus cells and type II or sustentacular cells. Glomus cells have afferent nerve endings, which are stimulated by hypoxia. Type II cells are glial cells and provide support for type I cells.

 

Type I glomus cells (carotid and aortic body) have O2-sensitive K+ channels. Conductance of these channels is reduced proportionally to the degree of hypoxia resulting in K+ efflux → depolarization of cell and causes Ca+ influx →Excitation of afferent nerve ending.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium: Calcium is also involved but primarily in response to the depolarization initiated by changes in potassium ion conductance. It is not the initial ion involved in oxygen sensing.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium ions are not directly involved in the oxygen-sensing mechanism of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. Chlorine: Chlorine ions are not involved in the oxygen-sensing functions of peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Potassium ions are crucial for the function of peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors, where they regulate the membrane potential and responsiveness of the cells to hypoxia. This process is vital for the body's ability to detect and respond to low oxygen levels, ensuring adequate oxygenation and cellular function.

questions.text: A patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia developed flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes. Which drug is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nicotinamide

 

Nicotinamide, also known as niacin, is a lipid-lowering agent commonly used in the treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. However, it is associated with several side effects that can limit its use. The most common and characteristic side effect of niacin is flushing, which is caused by the release of prostaglandins. This flushing can be intense and uncomfortable for patients, often leading to discontinuation of the drug.

 

In addition to flushing, niacin can cause hyperuricemia, which may precipitate gout, and it can also lead to hyperglycemia and insulin resistance. Furthermore, niacin is hepatotoxic, which can manifest as elevated liver enzymes.

 

While statins can also cause hyperglycemia and hepatotoxicity, they do not cause the flushing or gout that are characteristic of niacin use. Statins are more commonly associated with myopathy, which is not a feature in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atorvastatin: While atorvastatin, a statin, can cause hyperglycemia and raised liver enzymes, it is not typically associated with flushing or gout. Myopathy is the more significant side effect with statins.

 

Option B. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate, used to treat hypertriglyceridemia, may cause elevated liver enzymes and, rarely, hyperuricemia, but it is not associated with flushing or significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that is generally well tolerated and is not associated with the side effects of flushing, gout, or hyperglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicotinamide (niacin) is associated with flushing, gout, hyperglycemia, and raised liver enzymes, making it the likely cause of these symptoms in a patient being treated for hypertriglyceridemia

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the most appropriate method for the provisional diagnosis of Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) from pustular lesions. Group A streptococci characteristically show susceptibility to bacitracin, which serves as a key diagnostic feature in the laboratory. This susceptibility helps differentiate S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci. The test is performed by placing a bacitracin disk on a culture plate and observing for a zone of inhibition around the disk, which indicates susceptibility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity - This is incorrect because streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are catalase negative. The catalase test helps differentiate staphylococci (catalase positive) from streptococci (catalase negative). Finding catalase positivity would actually point away from streptococcal infection and toward staphylococcal infection.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity - This is incorrect because optochin sensitivity is specifically used for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococci), not Group A streptococci. S. pneumoniae is highly sensitive to optochin, while other streptococci including Group A are typically resistant.

 

Option C. Bile solubility - This is incorrect because the bile solubility test is used primarily for identifying Streptococcus pneumoniae. Pneumococci are soluble in bile whereas other streptococci, including Group A Streptococcus, are not bile soluble. This test would not help confirm a Group A streptococcal infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacitracin sensitivity testing is the key diagnostic test for the provisional identification of Group A Streptococcus from clinical specimens, with sensitivity to bacitracin being a distinctive characteristic that helps differentiate it from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Early-onset preeclampsia:
    • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
    • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
    • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
    • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
      • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
    • Biophysical Markers:
      • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
    • Biochemical Markers:
      • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
      • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
    • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
      • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.

 

Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.
