choices.text: Non-depolarizing and phase II depolarizing blockade

questions.text: In which type of neuromuscular blockade is a sustained response to a tetanic stimulus observed? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phase-I depolarizing blockade only.

 

In Phase-I depolarizing blockade (typical of succinylcholine at normal doses), there is a sustained response to tetanic stimulation without fade. This occurs because succinylcholine acts as an agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, causing prolonged depolarization of the muscle membrane. During Phase-I block, the neuromuscular monitoring shows characteristic features including absence of fade during tetanic stimulation

 

 

characteristic features including absence of fade during tetanic stimulation

 

Summary Table of Muscular Responses to Nerve Stimulation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-depolarizing blockade only: Incorrect because non-depolarizing agents (like vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium) competitively block acetylcholine receptors and produce a characteristic fade during tetanic stimulation.

 

Option C. Phase-II depolarizing blockade only: Incorrect because Phase-II block (which occurs with prolonged or high-dose succinylcholine administration) actually resembles non-depolarizing blockade with fade on tetanic stimulation. 

 

Option D. Non-depolarizing and phase II depolarizing blockade: Incorrect because both these types show fade during tetanic stimulation, not a sustained response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Only Phase-I depolarizing blockade (typical of standard-dose succinylcholine) produces a sustained response to tetanic stimulation without fade, which is a key distinguishing feature from both non-depolarizing blockade and Phase-II depolarizing blockade that both demonstrate fade

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

 

  • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.

 

Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 3 cm breast mass. The mass was excised, and microscopic examination reveals abundant extracellular mucin surrounding tumor cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucinous carcinoma of the breast

 

Mucinous carcinoma of the breast (also called colloid carcinoma) is characterized by the presence of abundant extracellular mucin surrounding clusters of tumor cells. This creates the distinctive histological appearance of "islands of tumor cells floating in lakes of mucin." Mucinous carcinoma typically presents as a well-circumscribed, soft, gelatinous mass and is more common in older women. It generally has a better prognosis than other types of invasive breast carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma of the breast: Incorrect. Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single file or "Indian file" pattern. The cells often have an intracytoplasmic lumen containing mucin (signet ring appearance), but the extracellular abundant mucin pools described in the question are not a feature of lobular carcinoma.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma of the breast: Incorrect. Medullary carcinoma features sheets of large, pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli and a syncytial growth pattern. It is typically well-circumscribed and has prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltration. Extracellular mucin is not a characteristic feature of medullary carcinoma.

 

Option D. Phyllodes tumor: Incorrect. Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial lesion characterized by leaf-like projections into cystic spaces. It has both epithelial and stromal components, with the stroma showing increased cellularity. Extracellular mucin is not a feature of phyllodes tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucinous carcinoma of the breast is characterized histologically by clusters of tumor cells floating in abundant extracellular mucin pools, giving it a distinctive appearance and generally conferring a better prognosis than other invasive breast carcinomas.

choices.text: Cisplatin is more neurotoxic than carboplatin
Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than carboplatin
Cisplatin causes more bone marrow suppression than carboplatin
Carboplatin causes more vomiting than cisplatin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about anticancer drugs is correct? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cisplatin is more nephrotoxic than carboplatin

 

Explanation:

 

 Cisplatin has three major adverse effects remembered with three C's:

 

  • C of ears – Ototoxicity (Irreversible)
  • C of kidney - Nephrotoxicity (most prominent)
  • C of smiling face - Maximum nausea and vomiting Cisplatin is known to be more nephrotoxic than carboplatin. 
  • Slow intravenous infusion is given
  • Saline loading should be done
  • Amifostine can be used (which can also prevent radiation-induced xerostomia)

 

To prevent nephrotoxicity:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cisplatin is more neurotoxic than carboplatin: Incorrect as carboplatin causes more neurotoxicity than cisplatin

 

Option C. Cisplatin causes more bone marrow suppression than carboplatin: Incorrect as cisplatin is one of the bone marrow-sparing anticancer drugs

 

Option D. Carboplatin causes more vomiting than cisplatin: Incorrect as cisplatin is the most emetogenic anticancer drug, causing maximum nausea and vomiting compared to other platinum compounds

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin has more nephrotoxicity compared to carboplatin, requiring preventive measures like slow IV infusion, saline loading and Amifostine.

 

Rescue Therapy

 

To teat advese effects pf amto-cancer drugs

questions.text: Till how many hours, eye donation is viable? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hrs

 

Explanation: 

 

In tropical countries, eye donation is viable for 6 hours from the time of death. During this critical time window, the cornea can be harvested for transplantation. 

 

  • Keep the entire eyeball or corneal-scleral button covered 
  • Short-term preservation: Moist chamber storage (up to 48 hours).
  • Medium-term preservation: McCarey-Kaufman (MK) medium or Optisol-GS (up to 7-14 days).
  • Long-term preservation: Organ culture or cryopreservation

 

Storage:

 

Educational Objective:


Eye donation is viable for 6 hours after death, and proper preservation techniques are crucial to maintain corneal tissue quality.

  • Time duration:
    1. In a tropical country – 4-6 hrs
    2. Colder countries – 12-24 hrs
  • Depends on the health of the donor cornea
  • Entire eyeball is retrieved and kept in a moist chamber for transportation to the eye bank
  • In the eye bank-corneoscleral button is cut and preserved
  • Most common organ transplant, no blood grouping matching or HLA matching is required

questions.text: What is the most radiosensitive phase of a cell cycle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G2M

 

The cell cycle consists of several phases, including the quiescent phase (G0), G1 phase, S phase, G2 phase, and M phase.

 

The G2/M phase of the cell cycle is the most radiosensitive. This phase is critical for cell division, involving DNA repair mechanisms and the process of mitosis. Radiosensitivity is heightened due to the cells’ high mitotic activity and the presence of condensed chromosomes, which are more susceptible to damage by radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S phase: Cells are synthesizing DNA and are somewhat resistant to radiation because DNA repair enzymes are active. S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option C. M phase: Although mitosis is a rapid process, its radiosensitivity is slightly less than G2/M phase.

 

Option D. G1 phase: This phase involves the growth and preparation of the cell for DNA synthesis; cells in G1 are less sensitive to radiation compared to G2/M.

 

Note – Phases of cell cycle –

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the repeating cycles in sequence during PCR? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Denaturation → Annealing → Extension

 

Explanation:

 

PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) follows a specific sequence of steps that repeat in cycles. The first step is denaturation, where heat is used to separate the double-stranded DNA into single strands. The second step is annealing, where primers bind to their complementary sequences on the separated DNA strands at a lower temperature. The final step is extension, where Taq polymerase synthesizes new DNA strands using the primers as starting points.

 

This three-step cycle is repeated multiple times, resulting in exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence. The PCR components include the DNA to be amplified, two primers (one for each strand), Taq polymerase enzyme, deoxyribonucleotides, and buffer with Mg²⁺.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Construction → Extension → Annealing: "Construction" is not a PCR step term. Additionally, extension must follow annealing since primers need to attach before DNA synthesis can begin.

 

Option B. Construction → Denaturation → Extension: Uses the non-standard term "construction" and omits the critical annealing step where primers bind to template DNA.

 

Option C. Construction → Annealing → Denaturation: Contains incorrect terminology and an illogical sequence, as denaturation begins each cycle, not ends it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PCR follows a precise cyclic pattern of denaturation (DNA strand separation), annealing (primer binding), and extension (DNA synthesis), which allows for exponential amplification of target DNA sequences.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. A barium swallow study is performed. Which characteristic radiological finding is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rat tail deformity

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia:

 

  • Young patient (25 years)
  • Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more
  • In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus
  • This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smooth filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests a benign mass/tumor 

 

Option C. Irregular filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests malignant mass causing infiltration of the esophageal wall

 

Option D. Corkscrew esophagus: Incorrect as this is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm where the primary symptom is chest pain rather than dysphagia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rat tail/bird beak appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of achalasia cardia, which presents with dysphagia to liquids more than solids.

questions.text: A 50-year-old presents with severe chest pain, respiratory distress, and crepitus after a fall from a roof. The X-ray image is shown. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pneumomediastinum

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray demonstrates air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum), visible as lucent streaks outlining mediastinal structures. This finding represents free air that has dissected through fascial planes into the mediastinum. Pneumomediastinum can result from trauma and typically presents with chest pain, respiratory distress, and subcutaneous emphysema (crepitus). The pattern shown matches classic pneumomediastinum signs.

 

Option C. Pneumomediastinum (CORRECT)

  • The image shows characteristic linear lucencies tracking along mediastinal structures
  • Air outlines the heart border, trachea, and great vessels
  • Associated with subcutaneous emphysema as evidenced by the patient's crepitus
  • Common after trauma due to alveolar rupture with air dissecting back along bronchovascular bundles

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post-pneumonectomy (INCORRECT)

  • Post-pneumonectomy shows complete opacification of one hemithorax
  • Would demonstrate surgical clips in the region of the hilum
  • Would show a shift of the heart and trachea toward the side of the pneumonectomy
  • Would have surgical absence of the 5th or 6th rib which is not seen here

 

Option B. Pulmonary laceration (INCORRECT)

  • Pulmonary laceration would appear as a focal area of consolidation in the lung parenchyma
  • Would not produce the linear lucent streaks in the mediastinum seen in this image
  • Represents a tear in the lung tissue following trauma, but doesn't cause mediastinal air
  • Would typically show focal hematoma or contusion patterns within lung fields

 

Option D. Flail chest (INCORRECT)

  • Flail chest requires multiple adjacent rib fractures in at least two places
  • While possible after a fall, the image does not show the multiple rib fractures defining this condition
  • Would demonstrate paradoxical motion of the chest wall during respiration clinically
  • Associated with underlying pulmonary contusion but not specifically with pneumomediastinum

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumomediastinum appears radiographically as linear lucencies outlining mediastinal structures and can occur after trauma through alveolar rupture with air dissecting along fascial planes, presenting with chest pain, respiratory distress, and subcutaneous emphysema.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female comes to the STI clinic with minimal vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, erosions are seen on the cervix. Which of the following kit should be given to this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Grey

 

The patient presents with erosions on the cervix, which is indicative of cervicitis. According to the syndromic management guidelines for sexually transmitted infections (STIs), cervicitis is treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1).

 

Educational Objective:  

 

STI color coded kits:

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with altered sensorium, persistent headache, and photophobia for the past 5 days. On examination, he has signs of meningeal irritation. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals:what is your diagnosis?
Protein: 93 mg/dL


Glucose: 20 mg/dL (serum glucose = 90 mg/dL)


Cell count: Predominantly lymphocytic pleocytosis (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tubercular meningitis

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is often associated with CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. These findings are consistent with the given CSF results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: The CSF findings of elevated protein, decreased glucose, and an increased number of neutrophil predominance (not lymphocytes) are suggestive of meningitis. However, bacterial meningitis is more commonly associated with a significantly higher white blood cell count (pleocytosis) in the CSF. The given CSF results are not typical for bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Viral meningitis: This is a potential consideration. Viral meningitis can present with elevated protein, normal or mildly reduced glucose, and an increased number of lymphocytes in the CSF. It is a common cause of aseptic (non-bacterial) meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following regimen is commonly used in the treatment of retinoblastoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine, carboplatin and etoposide

 

Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide.

 

Treatment of retinoblastoma –

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not commonly used for retinoblastoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used chemotherapy regimen for retinoblastoma includes vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. This combination is effective in reducing tumor size and facilitating further local treatment options.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

 

Competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor resembles the substrate and competes for binding to the active site of the enzyme. In the given graph, the presence of inhibitor A results in an increase in Km (Michaelis constant), indicating decreased enzyme affinity for the substrate due to competition. However, the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged, which is characteristic of competitive inhibition. The Lineweaver-Burk plot shows that the lines intersect on the y-axis, confirming that Vmax is unaffected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive inhibition: This type of inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a decrease in both Km and Vmax. The lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot are parallel, unlike the competitive inhibition plot seen here.

 

Option C. Mixed inhibition: In mixed inhibition, the inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme alone and the enzyme-substrate complex. This results in changes to both Km and Vmax, depending on the binding affinity. The graph shows altered Vmax with an intersection that is not on the y-axis, differing from competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. Non-competitive inhibition: Non-competitive inhibition occurs when the inhibitor binds to a site other than the active site, affecting the enzyme regardless of substrate binding. This results in decreased Vmax without altering Km, seen as lines intersecting on the x-axis in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, unlike the competitive inhibition pattern here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allograft arteriopathy

 

The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy.

 

Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Complications following cardiac transplantation:

 

Option A. Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.

 

Option C. Infection: Infection is common in organ transplant recipients. Bacteria and viruses account for more than 80% of infections after transplantation. The most common bacterial infections early after transplantation are nosocomial, caused by infected intravascular catheters or lines, or gram-negative pneumonias.

 

Renal dysfunction- Immunosuppressive therapy with calcineurin inhibitors has improved both graft function and survival in heart transplantation.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Following heart transplantation, malignancy is identified in 3% to 18% of the recipients, with an estimated risk of 1% to 2% per year. It ranks second to coronary vasculopathy as a major cause of mortality, accounting for 10% to 23% of all deaths following heart transplantation. Cutaneous malignancy is the most common type with a predominance of squamous cell carcinoma. Post-transplantation lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) is a frequently fatal complication, the peak occurrence of PTLD is 3 to 4 months after transplantation. A strong association of PTLD with Epstein-Barr virus has been observed in several series.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allograft arteriopathy is the foremost long-term limitation in cardiac transplantation, causing significant morbidity and mortality through progressive coronary stenosis.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

choices.text: Nil per oral to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Parentral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the nil per oral (NPO) approach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following should be avoided in management of the given condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administration of 5% dextrose 

 

The patient's presentation is suggestive of acute pancreatitis, characterized by severe abdominal pain radiating to the back and elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. The management of acute pancreatitis involves supportive care, including pain management, fluid resuscitation, and nutritional support. 

 

Administering solutions with high glucose content can increase triglyceride levels and potentially exacerbate pancreatitis, especially in a patient who is not eating. This could lead to hyperglycemia, which is why it should be avoided. The fluids preferred are RL or Normal saline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nil per oral (NPO) to avoid pancreatic stimulation: In acute pancreatitis, resting the pancreas by avoiding oral intake is a possible initial management step to prevent further pancreatic enzyme stimulation and reduce pancreatic workload.

 

Option C. Parenteral nutrition preferred for 2-3 days over the NPO approach: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is generally reserved for patients who cannot meet their nutritional requirements orally or enterally (via the gastrointestinal tract) after several days. The current trend is towards earlier enteral feeding when possible, rather than starting with parenteral nutrition. However, it is not a contra-indication.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feedings: If the patient is stable and pain is controlled, early initiation of oral feeding is recommended. This approach has been associated with a shorter hospital stay and lower complication rates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the administration of high glucose content solutions such as 5% dextrose, as they can exacerbate the condition, and instead focus on pain management, fluid resuscitation, and appropriate nutritional support.

choices.text: Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism
Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites
The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically greater than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

questions.text: A patient with decompensated liver cirrhosis presents with difficulty breathing due to significant ascites accumulation. Which of the following statements regarding the evaluation and cause of ascites is incorrect? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is typically less than 1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites

 

Explanation:

 

Ascites in cirrhosis is caused by portal hypertension, which increases hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity.

 

SAAG classification:

 

  • SAAG > 1.1 g/dL → Portal hypertension-related ascites (e.g., cirrhosis, heart failure, Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  • SAAG < 1.1 g/dL → Non-portal hypertension causes (e.g., malignancy, tuberculosis, pancreatitis)

 

Since cirrhosis-related ascites results from increased portal pressure, SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascites occurs due to secondary hyperaldosteronism: Correct; cirrhosis leads to RAAS activation, causing sodium and water retention

 

Option B. Simultaneous measurement of serum and ascitic fluid albumin levels is necessary: Correct; SAAG is calculated using these values

 

Option D. SAAG is typically >1.1 g/dL in cirrhosis-related ascites:  Correct, as it reflects portal hypertension

 

Educational Objective:

 

The SAAG value helps differentiate portal hypertension-related ascites (>1.1 g/dL) from non-portal hypertension causes (<1.1 g/dL).

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.text: Which of the following is true for non-parametric tests? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is used for skewed distributions 

 

  • Non-parametric tests are statistical tests that do not require the data to be normally distributed or have a specific population parameter, such as the mean or variance, assumed beforehand. They are typically used when the data are not normally distributed, have outliers, or when the sample size is small.
  • Some examples of non-parametric tests include the Wilcoxon rank-sum test, Kruskal-Wallis test, and Mann-Whitney U test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test:  Is incorrect because ANOVA is a parametric test used to compare the means of two or more groups.

 

Option C. It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution: Is incorrect because non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution.

 

Option D. It cannot be used for small sample sizes: Is also incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used for small sample sizes. In fact, they are often preferred over parametric tests for small sample sizes or when the assumptions of parametric tests are violated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-parametric tests are valuable statistical tools when dealing with skewed distributions or when the assumptions of parametric tests (like normal distribution) are not met. They provide robustness against the distribution shape of the data and are effective in handling smaller sample sizes and outliers.

questions.text: Which histological type of Wilms tumor has the worst prognosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Blastemal type

 

Explanation: 

 

Wilms tumor has varying prognosis based on its histological appearance. The blastemal predominant type generally has the worst prognosis among the various histological patterns. This is particularly true in post-chemotherapy specimens where predominant blastemal elements represent chemotherapy-resistant tissue. The blastemal component consists of primitive, undifferentiated cells with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and significant mitotic activity, contributing to its aggressive behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epithelial type - Epithelial predominant Wilms tumors generally have a better prognosis than blastemal type. These tumors show greater differentiation with tubular and glomeruloid structures.

 

Option B. Stromal type - Stromal predominant Wilms tumors typically have a favorable prognosis. These tumors contain differentiated mesenchymal elements and tend to be less aggressive.

 

Option D. Mixed type - Mixed type Wilms tumors contain relatively balanced proportions of all three components. They generally have an intermediate prognosis, better than blastemal type but potentially worse than purely epithelial or stromal types.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Blastemal predominant Wilms tumor carries the worst prognosis among the histological subtypes, particularly when persistent after chemotherapy, while more differentiated patterns (epithelial and stromal) generally have more favorable outcomes.
